answers.answer: JJ's mom,I'm a volunteer & a long-time diabetic.  We're not physicians here, so do check out the info provided with your son's endo.You have identified a very important characteristic of severe lows -- they often come in clusters exactly because of the glycogen depletion.  This is particularly pronounced when we must get a glucagon shot ... which causes the liver to DUMP just about all reserves into our bloodstream.  It's the right thing to do at times and yet we must be watched carefully for the next coupla DAYS for lows.  Once the crisis is over, our liver begins to "uptake" glucose from the bloodstream to rebuild its depleted glycogen stores.  The uptake can lead to a low ... and the cycle you noted can begin.My endo told me that it takes 2-3 good,normal meals and the absence of lows for a day or two to ensure the glycogen level is restored and our normal balance is intact, too.Exercise does the same work as insulin.  In a normal active child, it's so difficult to know how much is enough carbo/food to keep their levels stable, but it's better to err on the side of elevated BG than too low.  Check with your son's endo, but for adults exercising, we often need 15+ gms for every 15-20 minutes of aerobic-type exercise.Good luck with all this and try to reassure your son that "playing" won't always land him in the hospital.  As you both learn more and as he gets older and can verbalize the nuances of how he's feeling, it will get easier to catch these things earlier.  Still, I understand the fear and worry of all this ...

question: Hi, my 5 yr old son was diagnosed with type 1 Diabetes approximately two and a half years ago. He has, over the past 2-3 months become incredibly unstable with frequent hypoglycaemic episodes, resulting in loss of consciousness. There are a number of factors which may be influencing this,(?sickness, exercise,rapid metabolism of NPH, glycogen depletion?). He had a flu type illness a few weeks ago and his insulin requirements dropped to about half for several days( He has always required less during illness). He was admitted to hospital the following week to attempt stabilisation, but despite significant reductions in insulin dosing he managed several hypos. (We were however, charging around the grounds, playing games, and I had no idea at the time how much exercise affected blood sugars and reduced insulin requirements over the next 24 hours). He was also not eating as freely as he might at home.Eventually the insulin was cut back to such an extent that he swung into DKA which made him very sick. I have also noticed that following severe hypos treated with glucagon that he always has another rapid BS drop within a few hours, and that his insulin requirements drop sharply for 1-2 days. 3 days ago his BS was 5.4mmol/L (98) when I checked, and 15 mins later he behaved strangely and said he felt low. His BS was 1.6 (28) and 60 seconds later he was unconscious. This is typical of what is happening. Could a cycle of glycogen depletion be a contributory factor in variable insulin requirements and sensitivity? Any ideas?
title: Frequent Unconciousness/Variable Insulin Requirements in 5yr Old Type 1
